quoteFirst: He was obliged to take off his stockings to exhibit his feet, and even his jacket and waistcoat to show them the mode of his toilet. This exercise he was obliged to repeat the whole day.
quoteTime: About eight o'clock in the evening
quoteLast: , Ali sent him some kouskous and salt and water, being the only victuals he had tasted since the morning. During the night, the Moors kept a regular watch, and frequently looked into the hut to see if he was asleep.
title:
Travels of Richard and John Lander into the interior of Africa, for the discovery of the course and termination of the Niger

author: Huish, Robert, 1777-1850

quoteLast: , and then halted near a creek to feed horses and get supper. At 11 o'clock, the moon having risen, were ordered forward, and soon passed through the small town of Farmington.

quoteFirst: cut like a knife, and we suffered from it, not only on this occasion, but every day during the whole time we were in Tibet. It begins to blow with great fierceness and regularity at one o'clock in the afternoon, and it is only at
quoteLast: that it sometimes abates and gradually ceases. Frequently, however, the wind, instead of dropping at this time, increases in violence, blowing with terrible vehemence during the whole night.
title: In the forbidden land
author: Landor, Arnold Henry Savage, 1865-1924

quoteLast: when he galloped away, and at that hour it was quite dark.

quoteFirst: Our arrival at Venice was
quoteTime: about eight o’clock in the evening
quoteLast: , surely no time so fitting to be introduced to the fair Queen of the Adriatic.  From the busy, bustling railway station we were concluded by a Fakena, who brought up our luggage to a gondola lying in the shimmering sea just outside.
title:
From the Thames to the Tiber
or, My visit to Paris, Rome, Florence, Venice, Milan, Switzerland, etc.
author: Wardle, Joseph

quoteFirst: At
quoteLast: , a hurried note reached Alice Arden, at Mortlake. It was from her brother, and said,--
title: Checkmate

quoteFirst: A boy’s feeding arrangements were as follows: He would wake up about 2 a.m., having slept since
quoteLast: On his camp fire he would warm up a chunk of smoked elephant or buck meat. This he would not touch until the first halt in the day’s march, generally about 9 a.m. He would then have this first meal, consisting entirely of smoked beef.
title: The Wanderings of an Elephant Hunter
author: Bell, Walter Dalrymple Maitland, 1880-1954

quoteFirst: It was
quoteTime: about eight o’clock in the evening
quoteLast: of the same day when these scenes took place, that an old man, coming from a northern direction, entered the metropolis by the suburb of Pentonville.
title: The Mysteries of London, v. 4/4
author: Reynolds, George W. M. (George William MacArthur), 1814-1879

quoteFirst: The hatches were opened
quoteLast: ; but the provisions being so salt and sodden with the sea water, they could not be eaten, on account of the scarcity of fresh water. After the watch was set we laid ourselves down upon the upper-deck with no other covering than the starry heavens.
title: Narrative of a Voyage to India; of a Shipwreck on board the Lady Castlereagh; and a Description of New South Wales
author: Cramp, W. B.

quoteFirst: But my dear mother being now dangerously sick, I was, on the 3d of September following, sent for to Wotton. Whom I found so far spent, that, all human assistance failing, she in a most heavenly manner departed this life upon the 29th of the same month,
quoteLast: of Michaelmas-day. It was a malignant fever which took her away, about the 37th of her age, and 22d of her marriage, to our irreparable loss and the regret of all that knew her.
title: The Diary of John Evelyn (Volume 1 of 2)
author: Evelyn, John, 1620-1706; Garnett, Richard, 1835-1906 [Commentator]; Bray, William, 1736-1832 [Editor]

quoteFirst: A flag-wagger flutters his flag in eager question. Nothing moves on the plain save here and there a lonely prowling horseman, cantering on, or dismounted and peering through his glass. It was
quoteLast: when the first shot was fired.
title: With Rimington
author: Phillipps, L. March (Lisle March), 1863-1917

quoteFirst: Independent of the general disposition of ships of war in troublous times to overhaul and ascertain the business of any doubtful sail, Rodgers' orders prescribed the capture of vessels of certain character, even outside the three-mile limit; and, the "Little Belt" making sail from him, he pursued.
quoteLast: , it being then full dark, the character and force of the chase were still uncertain, and the vessels within range. The two accounts of what followed differ diametrically; but the British official version[352] is less exhaustive in matter and manner than the American, which rests upon the sworn testimony of numerous competent witnesses before a formal Court of Inquiry.
title: Sea Power in its Relations to the War of 1812. Volume 1
author: Mahan, A. T. (Alfred Thayer), 1840-1914

quoteFirst: I knew, however, that Strictland was well provided for, and being determined to visit him at the earliest opportunity, gave myself no further anxiety, but patiently awaited the return of the supercargo. I waited in vain; he did not arrive that day, but
quoteTime: about eight o'clock in the evening
quoteLast: a boat came off bringing a new captain, mate, and a couple of men. My short-lived reign was at an end! I had tasted the sweets of despotic authority for two delicious days.
title: Jack in the Forecastle; or, Incidents in the Early Life of Hawser Martingale
author: Sleeper, John Sherburne, 1794-1878

quoteFirst: We left Stockholm
quoteTime: about eight o'clock in the evening
quoteLast: . We were a party of four,--H and myself, and the two delightful friends whom we met that day at Maristuen, at the head of the Laera Dal, in Norway. The suggestions then first made had ripened into a definite plan, and we agreed to join forces for our journey through Russia.
title: Through Scandinavia to Moscow
author: Edwards, William Seymour, 1856-1915

quoteLast: , just as it grew dark; and they were then about two miles from the southernmost ship of the Danish line of defence.

quoteFirst: Now the Boers had possession of the whole stadt; again, as soon as night fell, large reinforcements were to force their way in. Of course we knew the Colonel was all the while maturing his plans to rid the town of the unbidden guests, but what these were no one could tell.
quoteLast: , when we were in the depth of despair, we got an official message to say that the Boers in the stadt had been surrounded and taken prisoners, and also that the fort had surrendered to Colonel Hore, who, with some of his officers, had been all day in the curious position of captives in their own barracks.
title:
South African Memories
Social, Warlike & Sporting from Diaries Written at the Time
author: Wilson, Sarah Isabella Augusta, Lady, 1865-1929
